articles.author: Falih Hassan and Alissa J. Rubin
articles.title: Iraq’s New Election Law Draws Much Criticism and Few Cheers
articles.description: Iraq’s Parliament voted to overhaul the country’s election laws in a bid to reduce the power of political parties. But many protesters, who had called for just such a change, were not impressed.
articles.content:
Legislators defended the new law, insisting that they were doing the will of the protesters. 
The political blocs listened to the demands of the demonstrators and carried out a peaceful coup upon themselves by passing the election law, said Wajih Abbas, a la… [+917 chars]

articles.author: Neil Vigdor
articles.title: Inquiry Into Michigan State’s Handling of Larry Nassar Case Is Suspended
articles.description: The university’s former president and former gymnastics coach are facing criminal prosecution as a result of the investigation, while a former dean was sentenced to one year in prison.
articles.content:
A Michigan State spokeswoman, Emily Guerrant, said in a statement Tuesday that the East Lansing university had complied with numerous investigations.
M.S.U. has cooperated fully with the inquiry, including handing over all facts associated with the case, the… [+1019 chars]

articles.author: JACK HEALY
articles.title: In Indian Country, a Crisis of Missing Women. And a New One When They’re Found.
articles.description: GALLUP, N.M. — Prudence Jones had spent two years handing out “Missing” flyers and searching homeless camps and underpasses for her 28-year-old daughter when she got the call she had been praying for: Dani had been found. She was in a New Mexico jail, but she…

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.title: 35 Civilians Killed in Extremist Attack in Burkina Faso
articles.description: The assault by Islamist extremists on a town in northern Burkina Faso also left 80 jihadists dead, according to the country’s president.
articles.content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso Jihadists attacked a town in northern Burkina Faso and killed 35 civilians, most of them women, and the ensuing clashes with security forces left 80 jihadists dead, the West African nations president, Roch Marc Christian Kaboré, anno… [+593 chars]

articles.title: Australia’s volunteer firefighters find it hard to pause, even for Christmas
articles.description: Australia’s Volunteer Firefighters Find It Hard to Pause, Even for Christmas

articles.author: The New York Times News Service Syndicate
articles.title: Pentagon eyes Africa drawdown as first step in global troop shift
articles.description: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper is weighing proposals for a major reduction — or even a complete pullout — of U.S. forces from West Africa as the first phase of reviewing global deployments.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper is weighing proposals for a major reduction or even a complete pullout of U.S. forces from West Africa as the first phase of reviewing global deployments that could reshuffle thousands of troops around the world, a… [+9023 chars]

articles.author: Ruth Maclean
articles.title: Nigeria Releases Leading Critic on Bail After a Campaign an Ocean Away
articles.description: Omoyele Sowore, a publisher and ex-presidential candidate, was released after months in detention. His New Jersey neighbors had led the effort to free him.
articles.content: Mr. Sowore still faces trial on charges of treason, money laundering and cyberstalking the last for allegedly insulting the president, Muhammadu Buhari, on television. His bail conditions stipulate that he may not leave the Nigerian capital, Abuja, or speak t… [+960 chars]

articles.description: The former president’s annual year-end playlist never fails to delight.

articles.author: Brittan Heller
articles.title: How to Teach an Old Frog New Tricks
articles.description: Pepe, Gaysper and other once-hateful symbols teach us that tech companies should institutionalize impermanence.
